instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476A: What is 820-3476A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGOD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGOD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS_PWRGOD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD: What is SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD? SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a pre-requisite for SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK..
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NO BRAIN
threads.message:
Hi guys, sorry about my English. This is an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that arrived without power on.
The SMC looks reflowed and liquid damage around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.
I change <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and now the board turn on but not fan spin, no chime, and no usb activity.
I try a good efi bios and still no brain

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>.        1.74v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>                   3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>                 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP0V675_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>   0.675v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>                        3.3v
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>                     0v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>     0v

Diode mode
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> 0.045v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> 0.045v

Resistence
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> 40ohm
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> 40ohm

The pad on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> are good and just in case change the chip and still the same

threads.message: here may be the problem, this signal is generated by <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> SMC. But some transistor may be blocking the signal. If I already change <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NO BRAIN
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Mac Tech, post: 88901, member: 34050"]
here may be the problem, this signal is generated by <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> SMC. But some transistor may be blocking the signal. If I already change <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
[/QUOTE]
I suspect that the smc could cause the trouble because it was reflowed previusly. 
Need a donor for this SMC. Soon update with the result. Thanks for the help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NO BRAIN
threads.message:
Try reballing original SMC first.

If you get 3V at pin 6 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, tie together pins 5/6 and test again the board.
